HOPKINS CORPS WILL BE READY J. H. U. WINS GEORGETOWN MEET

COLLEGE MEN TO HELP NATION

THURSDAY COMMEMORATION DAY

Is Learning Manual of Arms—In Case
of War, Officers Will Be Given
Commissions in United
States Army.

Black and Billie Runners Capture Three
First Places, With Total Score of
24 Points—Georgetown
Wins Second.

Form Bureau to Assist Government in
Organization of Country's Resources.
Guy T.0. Hollyday of Hopkins
Made Secretary.

Forty-first Anniversary of University's
Founding — Ex-President Taft to
Speak on Extension of
FederalPower.

The present drill hours of the
Reserve Officers' Training Corps
are being spent at the Fourth
Regiment Armory in learning 'the
manual of arms, in order that its
members may be prepared to
serve in case of war.
If war should be declared, the
battalion would not be called out,
as the Government does not employ such a corps in warfare. All
the commissioned officers, however, and many of the sergeants,
are prepared to execute commissions in the Regular Army or
militia, and the corps members
of military age would be expected
to enlist in one of these two organizations.
Lieutenant Elliott is planning
to give additional drills if war becomes more imminent, and if war
should be declared, drills would
be held every (lay; provided that
the sanction of the authorities
could be obtained.
On this Saturday a big tactical
problem will be conducted in conjunction with the Polytechnic and
City College companies in the
neighborhood of Pikesville, which
will last all the afternoon. The
present plans are .for the cadets
to occupy and outpost a position,
while the Hopkins battalion is to
locate it by patrolling and then
to attack it. Lieutenant Elliott
and other officers will judge the
carrying out of the problem, and
will decide upon the winner of
the.imaginary encounter.
The progress of the corps is
very gratifying to Lieutenant V1liott, and he hopes that even
swifter strides will be made in
the near future. The recent examinations brought about many
changes in the battalion, especially in the personnel of the nonSeveral
commissioned officers.
sergeants and corporals were replaced by privates who have been
showing up well in drills and in
the examinations, and several honorable discharges were granted.
From now on appointments
will be based on the outcome of
examinations, attendance, interest and improvement. The men
who stand highest in all these are
in line for promotion. All the
officers for next year will be decided upon at the end of this term,
and in all probability numerous
changes will be made in the meantime in the roster of "non-corns."
Company C,under Captain Thompson, had the highest average in
the past examinations, with a composite grade of 80 per cent.

Winning first and second places
in three of the most important
events, and doing creditable work
in several others, the Johns Hopkins track team captured the
point trophy at the Georgetown
University track and field meet
last Saturday night at Convention
Hall, Washington, with a total of
24 points.
Georgetown, the nearest competitor, had a total of 20 points,
followed by _Maryland State, with
three and Washington and Lee,
with two.
This was the first of a series of
meets constituting probably the
heaviest track schedule Johns
Hopkins has ever had, and was
watched with a great deal of interest as being the first practical
testing out of the teams.
Hall carried off first place in
the 440-yard open, with Winslow
second and Grace, of Maryland
State, third. Bernhart and Perkins were first and second in the
open mile run, with Campbell,
of Georgetown, third. Captain
Straus won the 880-yard open,with
Weeks second and Chipman, of
Maryland State, third.
Other Johns Hopkins athletes
to place were Dempster, fifth in
the South Atlantic 50-yard hurdles; Mountford, tied with Wingate, of George Washington, for
third in the high jump; and Leadbetter, third in the shotput.
Catholic University and Georgetown won'the feature relay races.
The former captured the first
mile relay from George Washington rather easily, while the latter
did very creditable work in defeating the relay team of Lehigh
University in fast time. .
The summaries:

The college men of the country
started a concentrated action to
help the country in its preparations for possible war last Saturday, when the Intercollegiate Intelligence Bureau was organized
in Washington.
The movement was originated
by Dean William McClelland, of
the University of Pennsylvania,
and proposes to prepare for the
use of the Government lists of college students, professors. and
alumni who are especially trained
and competent to aid the country
in time of war. The bureau also
plans to have any of these men,
at the request of the Government,
carry on investigations and do
such practical work as the Government may find necessary.
The Secretary of War, the Secretary of the Navy, Major-General
Leonard Wood, Rear Admiral
Fiske, George W. Wickersham
and other prominent men have expressed themselves as entirely in
favor of the plan. About fifty colleges and universities of the East
were -repre.sented at the meeting,
and it was planned to extend the
organization to every State and
practically to every college, university and technical institution
in the country.
Dean McClelland was made
chairman and Guy T. 0. Hollyday, of Hopkins, was made secretary of the temporary organization. Later permanent officers
were elected as follows:
Director—William McClelland.
Treasurer—Charles W. Howe,
of George Washington University.
Executive Committee — MajorGeneral W. C. Gorgas, U. S. A.;
David G. Hill, former Ambassador
to Germany; and W. S. Gifford,
secretary of Council for National
Defense.

Final plans for the forty-first
anniversary of the opening of the
Johns Hopkins University, to be
publicly observed on Thursday,
February 22, 1917, have been formulated. The Hon. William Howard Taft, of New Haven, Conn.,
will be the principal speaker. His
subject will be "Wise and Unwise
Extension of Federal Power."
The Rev. Romilly Humphries, rector of Grace and St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church, will be
chaplain. The direction of the
music, as usual, will be in the
hands of Mr. Edwin L. Turnbull.
The exercises will be held in the
Lyric Theatre. The trustees and
faculty will assemble at half-past
ten o'clock in the hall over the
main lobby. The official guests—
the representatives from other colleges, city and State officials, etc.
—are requested to proceed at once
to seats on the first floor, which
will be reserved until a quarter
before eleven. They are asked to
present the cards accompanying
the invitation.
The alumni will assemble at
half-past ten in the lower hall on
Maryland avenue, whence they
will proceed to reserved seats in
the auditorium.
It has been customary each
year at this time for the alumni
to hold a meeting and an annual
banquet. lip to this time, however, no definite plans have been
made for this function, and it is
thought that the banquet at least
will be omitted.
The students will meet at twenty minutes past ten in the same
place and will proceed, under the
direction of their marshals, to
seats reserved for them. Professor Matthews has consented to act
as chief marshal, and William
Baker, Jr., will be chief usher.
The procession will enter the
auditorium at a quarter before
eleven. The boxes will be reserved
until that time for the families
of the trustees and faculty, as will
the seats on the first floor not required for the procession and a
portion of the balcony for other
persons holding cards. After the
procession has entered, the remaining seats will be free to the
public. The exercises will begin
punctually at eleven o'clock and
will close probably before one
o'clock. .

dent to the world that there is
a higher international morality
than that of national desire, that
the law between nations is not
a slender thread, to be broken at
will, but'a bond which every faculty, of man's higher sense- demands must be acknowledged and
strengthened, until the futile anarchy of war has become a thing
impossible.
This is the duty which falls
upon the class of which we Hopkins men are a part—to keep ever
before our eyes the concept of
this higher morality, to fight, if
fight we must, not to kill as many
of a people as we may, because
the red flush of war has made us
see every one of that people as a
beast and a barbarian, but to
make the truth of that concept
prevail.
There is a growing class of
men among the nations of the
world who are today thinking the
same thoughts, working for the
same ends. Such men — varied
enough in type—are Norman Angell, H. G. Wells and Maximilian
Harden. For them, and for the
men who are with them, nationality has become subordinate to the
innate brotherhood of man; they
are trying, in sane, practical way,
to realize the creed taught by every
great religion the world has ever
produced.
The shibboleth of
their creed is law for all nations
—the abolition of war. Whether
the United States is drawn into
the Great War or whether it is
not, it is under this creed that we
must enlist—it is for us, the college men of America, to take the
lead in this country in proving
that the beauty of an ideal is no
longer sufficient cause for damning it as an impractical dream.
• The man at the head of our
Country ioday is a Hopkins man.
At the present moment, even with
a reluctance which none can ever
doubt, he is making ready for

potent. Hopkins men know it as

The Highest Duty.

At this time, when our country is upon the verge of war with
Germany, a tremendous obligation rests upon every college man.
The mouthing of vague platitudes
is not enough, loyal and wholehearted patriotism is not enough;
if all education is not to prove a
gaudy tinsel designed for moments
of luxitry. alone, the great body of
American students- must realize,
and realize with an intensity deep
enough to become a national force,
where, as a country, we stand, and
what, as a country, we desire.
That, if war is declared, the
call for men will meet with an
instantaneous response from the
Pacific to the Atlantic can be
taken as a matter of fact. When
that time comes, if it is to come,
the men of Our colleges will answer the appeal as enthusiastically as the men. of the European
universities responded to the call
of their governments, as enthusia4ically as volunteered the generations of American students before them in the War of S.ecession and the War with Spain.
So much must we all do; that
is the easiest. What is the hardest, the most fundamental thing
of all, is for us to make ready for
war, with the knowledge always
before us that we want, not war,
but peace. We are grasping the
sword, not to extend the lines of
our boundaries, but to make evi-

A Successful Innovation.

Entirely apart from the fact
that the mere ending of examinations is apt to cast an optimistic tinge over all philosophic reflections for the next few weeks
following, there seems to be little
dissent in the University from the
opinion that the semester system

which those examinations introduced is a distinct improvement
over the old three-term pldn.
In the first place, of course,
there is the obvious advantage of
having two sets of examinations
during the year instead of three.
Theoretically, the midyears, coming a month or so later than did
the first-term examinations under
the old system, should necessitate
more studying; but, in practice,
the work of preparation for any
examinations is heavy enough in
itself to make the additional review necessitated hardly noticeable—the real strain of the examination period comes in the nervous tension engendered by its approach.
Moreover, under the present semester plan, with the end of the
midyears, the work of the first
half year is definitely over—there
is no frantic cramming of forgotten details at the last moment
before the finals, no doubling of
the time of preparation needed
for the first examinations. The
University, under the present system, can face .the second half of
the collegiate year with the satisfying knowledge that it has come
to a new leaf in reality, without
the ghosts of the letters of previous chapters still hanging about
the. pages.
More and more, during the past
few years, the undergraduate
courses have been dividing themselves naturally, into parts—philosophy, political economy II and
III, several of the sciences — in
these and many more there is a
distinct break in the subject matter studied, which makes the division of the year into two parts
instead of three far more satisfactory. In most of the large colleges, indeed, each undergraduate
coutse is given for only a half
year, the entire schedule of each
man being changed after midyears. The present Hopkins system is a very sane compromise—
courses comprehensive enough to
last through the year, yet tending
naturally to fall into two subdivisions.
The Hopkins undergraduate has
but one point of complaint—there
is no recess after the strain of the
midyears before the next semester
begins. Undeniably, under the
old system, there was something
peculiarly satisfying in the idea
that the period of examinations
was to be followed by a period of
very distinct relaxation; and,
equally undeniably, the return to
college last Monday was an occasion by no means joyful. Nevertheless, the difference between
writing examination papers and
attending classes is great enough
to make the second occupation
seem extremely light by comparison—and there are always rosy
dreams of the future, in which an
unquenchable belief in the inherent benevolence of the Hopkins
faculty plays a very prominent
part.

TO PROVIDE LABORATORY FOR
COAL GAS BY-PRODUCTS WORK

Steady progress is being made
in the work of erection of a laboratory for research in coal gas byproduct recovery in the small
stone building at the southeast
corner of the University grounds,
formerly known as "The Lodge."
It is possible that the apparatus
may be ready for use before the
end of the present scholastic year.
Several thousand dollars have
been subscribed by the large coal
gas manufacturers of the country
to provide for the erection and
maintenance of this laboratory,
which is to be under the joint supervision of the depaytment of
chemistry and the department of
engineering.
As considerable interest in a
series of lectures given on byproduct recovery was shown by
many of the students in both these
departments it is expected that
them will take up the
a number of'
work in the new laboratory as
soon as the apparatus is installed.

Safe Deposit and Crust Company

REGARDING CLASS ABSENCES

The following rules were passed
at a meeting of the Committee on
Academic Rules and Regulations
last Saturday, to go into effect
mmediately:
1., Instructors shall report all
absences promptly they will not
hereafter accept excuses.
2. Students having excuses for
absence may present them to the
Committee on Academic Rules
and Regulations, which will meet
on Wednesdays at 1 P. M., in
Room 218.
3. Unexcused absences will
count against the student's term
mark in the subjects concerned.
4. Unexcused absences incurred
immediately before or after all
holidays, vacations and examination periods will be counted
double.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY 19, 1917.

INTER-CLASS DEBATE UNDER WAY

MAINTAINS HOPKINS' STANDARD

Seniors and Juniors to Clash on March
.3—Committees for Arrangements
Appointed—Contest Will Be
Held at Homewood.

Second Cotillon Has Attendance of Over
Seventy-five--Pretty Girls,Plenteous
Refreshments,and '`Louie" Fisher
Contribute to Success.

An important meeting of the
Debating Council was held last
Wednesday to complete arrangements for .the annual JuniorSenior inter-class debate, to be
held in the Civil Engineering assembly hall on Saturday evening,
March 3.
The following committees have
been appointed to take charge of
the affair:
General Committee of Arrangements—Cecil Bagley (chairman),
Allan Chalmers, Adolf Hamburger and John Doermann.
Committee on Invitations—Fred
Hall (chairman), William Kendall, Jr., and Beverly Smith, Jr.
Ushers—Robert France (chairman), W. F. Cromwell, Ed. Jarrett, A. W. Jacobsen, Malcolm
Marty and C. Stansbury.
With the debate less than two
weeks away, the members of the
teams are hard at work getting;
their material in shape. The subject of the debate has been
changed so as to lilt& the discussion to interstate railroads and
now reads: "Resolved,- that constitutionality waived,legislation providing for the compulsory arbitration of all labor disputes in interstate railways and prohibiting all
strikes and lockouts on such railways should be enacted."
The Seniors have the negative
side of the question. Although it
has not been definitely decided,
the order of the 'speakers for the
two teams will in all probability
be as follows:
Juniors—Rothschild, Evans and
Duncan.
Seniors — Ed gett, Oppenheimer
and Steinbach.
As has been the custom in past
years, the Johns Hopkins Musical
Clubs will render selections on
the evening of the debate.
In addition to the debate, there
will be a public speaking contest
for the Adams medal between
three members of the Sophomore
Class—Mitchell B. Carroll, Maurice Glick and Corydon P. Gowman, Jr.
The arrangements for the intercollegiate debate are nearly complete, with the exception of the
selection of a date. It is thought,
however, that April 21 will be satisfactory to all concerned. Both
the University of Virginia and the
University of North Carolina have
agreed to the amended subject,
limiting the discussion to interstate railroads, which will be the
subject of the inter class debate.
The date for the Tocqueville
medal contest will be announced
next week. The Tocqueville medal
is annually given to the Johns
Hopkins University by the Baron
Pierre de Coubertin of Paris, and
University to

With an attendance of over
seventy-five couples, the second
cotillon of the year was held last
Friday in the Civil Engineering
Building.
Pretty girls blended with various class pennants dating back to
the days of University infancy,
while spritely young Hopkins students tripped the light fantastic
to their hearts' content. Louis
Fisher's orchestra blared forth
in sonorous tones syncopated
waltzes, fox-trots and one-steps.
At the end of the tenth dance
there was a triumphant march to
the "eats," which disappeared in
a manner clearly showing that
they were thoroughly enjoyed.
After this intermission all rushed
back to take up their terpsichorean duties.
At 1 o'clock the last strains of
"Home, Sweet Home" rolled out
across the campus, lights were
dimmed and the dancers wended
their way home.

AFTERWARD
Those awful days, those days of fearsome dread;
Those madd'ning nights, those nights of midnight oil,
Are gone, all gone. No longer need I toil
And force crammed knowledge through my aching head.
I think no more of penicillium thread,
No more of charter colony, or royal,
Of George's unearned produce of the soil,
Or anything that Mill or Bacon said.
My step is firm again, my head is high,
No longer.do I shrink from each new day.
The clouds'are gone; the sun shines in the sky;
And joyously I leap, and shout, and play..,
Away, ye books! Unlooked at shall ye lie
And gather dust until the end of May.

HOPKINS CORPS WILL BE READY J. H. U. WINS GEORGETOWN MEET

COLLEGE MEN TO HELP NATION

THURSDAY COMMEMORATION DAY

Is Learning Manual of Arms—In Case
of War, Officers Will Be Given
Commissions in United
States Army.

Black and Billie Runners Capture Three
First Places, With Total Score of
24 Points—Georgetown
Wins Second.

Form Bureau to Assist Government in
Organization of Country's Resources.
Guy T.0. Hollyday of Hopkins
Made Secretary.

Forty-first Anniversary of University's
Founding — Ex-President Taft to
Speak on Extension of
FederalPower.

The present drill hours of the
Reserve Officers' Training Corps
are being spent at the Fourth
Regiment Armory in learning 'the
manual of arms, in order that its
members may be prepared to
serve in case of war.
If war should be declared, the
battalion would not be called out,
as the Government does not employ such a corps in warfare. All
the commissioned officers, however, and many of the sergeants,
are prepared to execute commissions in the Regular Army or
militia, and the corps members
of military age would be expected
to enlist in one of these two organizations.
Lieutenant Elliott is planning
to give additional drills if war becomes more imminent, and if war
should be declared, drills would
be held every (lay; provided that
the sanction of the authorities
could be obtained.
On this Saturday a big tactical
problem will be conducted in conjunction with the Polytechnic and
City College companies in the
neighborhood of Pikesville, which
will last all the afternoon. The
present plans are .for the cadets
to occupy and outpost a position,
while the Hopkins battalion is to
locate it by patrolling and then
to attack it. Lieutenant Elliott
and other officers will judge the
carrying out of the problem, and
will decide upon the winner of
the.imaginary encounter.
The progress of the corps is
very gratifying to Lieutenant V1liott, and he hopes that even
swifter strides will be made in
the near future. The recent examinations brought about many
changes in the battalion, especially in the personnel of the nonSeveral
commissioned officers.
sergeants and corporals were replaced by privates who have been
showing up well in drills and in
the examinations, and several honorable discharges were granted.
From now on appointments
will be based on the outcome of
examinations, attendance, interest and improvement. The men
who stand highest in all these are
in line for promotion. All the
officers for next year will be decided upon at the end of this term,
and in all probability numerous
changes will be made in the meantime in the roster of "non-corns."
Company C,under Captain Thompson, had the highest average in
the past examinations, with a composite grade of 80 per cent.

Winning first and second places
in three of the most important
events, and doing creditable work
in several others, the Johns Hopkins track team captured the
point trophy at the Georgetown
University track and field meet
last Saturday night at Convention
Hall, Washington, with a total of
24 points.
Georgetown, the nearest competitor, had a total of 20 points,
followed by _Maryland State, with
three and Washington and Lee,
with two.
This was the first of a series of
meets constituting probably the
heaviest track schedule Johns
Hopkins has ever had, and was
watched with a great deal of interest as being the first practical
testing out of the teams.
Hall carried off first place in
the 440-yard open, with Winslow
second and Grace, of Maryland
State, third. Bernhart and Perkins were first and second in the
open mile run, with Campbell,
of Georgetown, third. Captain
Straus won the 880-yard open,with
Weeks second and Chipman, of
Maryland State, third.
Other Johns Hopkins athletes
to place were Dempster, fifth in
the South Atlantic 50-yard hurdles; Mountford, tied with Wingate, of George Washington, for
third in the high jump; and Leadbetter, third in the shotput.
Catholic University and Georgetown won'the feature relay races.
The former captured the first
mile relay from George Washington rather easily, while the latter
did very creditable work in defeating the relay team of Lehigh
University in fast time. .
The summaries:

The college men of the country
started a concentrated action to
help the country in its preparations for possible war last Saturday, when the Intercollegiate Intelligence Bureau was organized
in Washington.
The movement was originated
by Dean William McClelland, of
the University of Pennsylvania,
and proposes to prepare for the
use of the Government lists of college students, professors. and
alumni who are especially trained
and competent to aid the country
in time of war. The bureau also
plans to have any of these men,
at the request of the Government,
carry on investigations and do
such practical work as the Government may find necessary.
The Secretary of War, the Secretary of the Navy, Major-General
Leonard Wood, Rear Admiral
Fiske, George W. Wickersham
and other prominent men have expressed themselves as entirely in
favor of the plan. About fifty colleges and universities of the East
were -repre.sented at the meeting,
and it was planned to extend the
organization to every State and
practically to every college, university and technical institution
in the country.
Dean McClelland was made
chairman and Guy T. 0. Hollyday, of Hopkins, was made secretary of the temporary organization. Later permanent officers
were elected as follows:
Director—William McClelland.
Treasurer—Charles W. Howe,
of George Washington University.
Executive Committee — MajorGeneral W. C. Gorgas, U. S. A.;
David G. Hill, former Ambassador
to Germany; and W. S. Gifford,
secretary of Council for National
Defense.

Final plans for the forty-first
anniversary of the opening of the
Johns Hopkins University, to be
publicly observed on Thursday,
February 22, 1917, have been formulated. The Hon. William Howard Taft, of New Haven, Conn.,
will be the principal speaker. His
subject will be "Wise and Unwise
Extension of Federal Power."
The Rev. Romilly Humphries, rector of Grace and St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church, will be
chaplain. The direction of the
music, as usual, will be in the
hands of Mr. Edwin L. Turnbull.
The exercises will be held in the
Lyric Theatre. The trustees and
faculty will assemble at half-past
ten o'clock in the hall over the
main lobby. The official guests—
the representatives from other colleges, city and State officials, etc.
—are requested to proceed at once
to seats on the first floor, which
will be reserved until a quarter
before eleven. They are asked to
present the cards accompanying
the invitation.
The alumni will assemble at
half-past ten in the lower hall on
Maryland avenue, whence they
will proceed to reserved seats in
the auditorium.
It has been customary each
year at this time for the alumni
to hold a meeting and an annual
banquet. lip to this time, however, no definite plans have been
made for this function, and it is
thought that the banquet at least
will be omitted.
The students will meet at twenty minutes past ten in the same
place and will proceed, under the
direction of their marshals, to
seats reserved for them. Professor Matthews has consented to act
as chief marshal, and William
Baker, Jr., will be chief usher.
The procession will enter the
auditorium at a quarter before
eleven. The boxes will be reserved
until that time for the families
of the trustees and faculty, as will
the seats on the first floor not required for the procession and a
portion of the balcony for other
persons holding cards. After the
procession has entered, the remaining seats will be free to the
public. The exercises will begin
punctually at eleven o'clock and
will close probably before one
o'clock. .

1110 J011118 [101)1(ill3 NOW -{0101

dent to the world that there is
a higher international morality
than that of national desire, that
the law between nations is not
a slender thread, to be broken at
will, but'a bond which every faculty, of man's higher sense- demands must be acknowledged and
strengthened, until the futile anarchy of war has become a thing
impossible.
This is the duty which falls
upon the class of which we Hopkins men are a part—to keep ever
before our eyes the concept of
this higher morality, to fight, if
fight we must, not to kill as many
of a people as we may, because
the red flush of war has made us
see every one of that people as a
beast and a barbarian, but to
make the truth of that concept
prevail.
There is a growing class of
men among the nations of the
world who are today thinking the
same thoughts, working for the
same ends. Such men — varied
enough in type—are Norman Angell, H. G. Wells and Maximilian
Harden. For them, and for the
men who are with them, nationality has become subordinate to the
innate brotherhood of man; they
are trying, in sane, practical way,
to realize the creed taught by every
great religion the world has ever
produced.
The shibboleth of
their creed is law for all nations
—the abolition of war. Whether
the United States is drawn into
the Great War or whether it is
not, it is under this creed that we
must enlist—it is for us, the college men of America, to take the
lead in this country in proving
that the beauty of an ideal is no
longer sufficient cause for damning it as an impractical dream.
• The man at the head of our
Country ioday is a Hopkins man.
At the present moment, even with
a reluctance which none can ever
doubt, he is making ready for
combat, he is the greatest teacher
of the creed among us. After all,
it is an old, old creed; it has been
phrased many times, and with

The Highest Duty.

At this time, when our country is upon the verge of war with
Germany, a tremendous obligation rests upon every college man.
The mouthing of vague platitudes
is not enough, loyal and wholehearted patriotism is not enough;
if all education is not to prove a
gaudy tinsel designed for moments
of luxitry. alone, the great body of
American students- must realize,
and realize with an intensity deep
enough to become a national force,
where, as a country, we stand, and
what, as a country, we desire.
That, if war is declared, the
call for men will meet with an
instantaneous response from the
Pacific to the Atlantic can be
taken as a matter of fact. When
that time comes, if it is to come,
the men of Our colleges will answer the appeal as enthusiastically as the men. of the European
universities responded to the call
of their governments, as enthusia4ically as volunteered the generations of American students before them in the War of S.ecession and the War with Spain.
So much must we all do; that
is the easiest. What is the hardest, the most fundamental thing
of all, is for us to make ready for
war, with the knowledge always
before us that we want, not war,
but peace. We are grasping the
sword, not to extend the lines of
our boundaries, but to make evi-

A Successful Innovation.

Entirely apart from the fact
that the mere ending of examinations is apt to cast an optimistic tinge over all philosophic reflections for the next few weeks
following, there seems to be little
dissent in the University from the
opinion that the semester system

which those examinations introduced is a distinct improvement
over the old three-term pldn.
In the first place, of course,
there is the obvious advantage of
having two sets of examinations
during the year instead of three.
Theoretically, the midyears, coming a month or so later than did
the first-term examinations under
the old system, should necessitate
more studying; but, in practice,
the work of preparation for any
examinations is heavy enough in
itself to make the additional review necessitated hardly noticeable—the real strain of the examination period comes in the nervous tension engendered by its approach.
Moreover, under the present semester plan, with the end of the
midyears, the work of the first
half year is definitely over—there
is no frantic cramming of forgotten details at the last moment
before the finals, no doubling of
the time of preparation needed
for the first examinations. The
University, under the present system, can face .the second half of
the collegiate year with the satisfying knowledge that it has come
to a new leaf in reality, without
the ghosts of the letters of previous chapters still hanging about
the. pages.
More and more, during the past
few years, the undergraduate
courses have been dividing themselves naturally, into parts—philosophy, political economy II and
III, several of the sciences — in
these and many more there is a
distinct break in the subject matter studied, which makes the division of the year into two parts
instead of three far more satisfactory. In most of the large colleges, indeed, each undergraduate
coutse is given for only a half
year, the entire schedule of each
man being changed after midyears. The present Hopkins system is a very sane compromise—
courses comprehensive enough to
last through the year, yet tending
naturally to fall into two subdivisions.
The Hopkins undergraduate has
but one point of complaint—there
is no recess after the strain of the
midyears before the next semester
begins. Undeniably, under the
old system, there was something
peculiarly satisfying in the idea
that the period of examinations
was to be followed by a period of
very distinct relaxation; and,
equally undeniably, the return to
college last Monday was an occasion by no means joyful. Nevertheless, the difference between
writing examination papers and
attending classes is great enough
to make the second occupation
seem extremely light by comparison—and there are always rosy
dreams of the future, in which an
unquenchable belief in the inherent benevolence of the Hopkins
faculty plays a very prominent
part.

TO PROVIDE LABORATORY FOR
COAL GAS BY-PRODUCTS WORK

Steady progress is being made
in the work of erection of a laboratory for research in coal gas byproduct recovery in the small
stone building at the southeast
corner of the University grounds,
formerly known as "The Lodge."
It is possible that the apparatus
may be ready for use before the
end of the present scholastic year.
Several thousand dollars have
been subscribed by the large coal
gas manufacturers of the country
to provide for the erection and
maintenance of this laboratory,
which is to be under the joint supervision of the depaytment of
chemistry and the department of
engineering.
As considerable interest in a
series of lectures given on byproduct recovery was shown by
many of the students in both these
departments it is expected that
them will take up the
a number of'
work in the new laboratory as
soon as the apparatus is installed.

Safe Deposit and Crust Company
of Baltimore

REGARDING CLASS ABSENCES

The following rules were passed
at a meeting of the Committee on
Academic Rules and Regulations
last Saturday, to go into effect
mmediately:
1., Instructors shall report all
absences promptly they will not
hereafter accept excuses.
2. Students having excuses for
absence may present them to the
Committee on Academic Rules
and Regulations, which will meet
on Wednesdays at 1 P. M., in
Room 218.
3. Unexcused absences will
count against the student's term
mark in the subjects concerned.
4. Unexcused absences incurred
immediately before or after all
holidays, vacations and examination periods will be counted
double.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY 19, 1917.

INTER-CLASS DEBATE UNDER WAY

MAINTAINS HOPKINS' STANDARD

Seniors and Juniors to Clash on March
.3—Committees for Arrangements
Appointed—Contest Will Be
Held at Homewood.

Second Cotillon Has Attendance of Over
Seventy-five--Pretty Girls,Plenteous
Refreshments,and '`Louie" Fisher
Contribute to Success.

An important meeting of the
Debating Council was held last
Wednesday to complete arrangements for .the annual JuniorSenior inter-class debate, to be
held in the Civil Engineering assembly hall on Saturday evening,
March 3.
The following committees have
been appointed to take charge of
the affair:
General Committee of Arrangements—Cecil Bagley (chairman),
Allan Chalmers, Adolf Hamburger and John Doermann.
Committee on Invitations—Fred
Hall (chairman), William Kendall, Jr., and Beverly Smith, Jr.
Ushers—Robert France (chairman), W. F. Cromwell, Ed. Jarrett, A. W. Jacobsen, Malcolm
Marty and C. Stansbury.
With the debate less than two
weeks away, the members of the
teams are hard at work getting;
their material in shape. The subject of the debate has been
changed so as to lilt& the discussion to interstate railroads and
now reads: "Resolved,- that constitutionality waived,legislation providing for the compulsory arbitration of all labor disputes in interstate railways and prohibiting all
strikes and lockouts on such railways should be enacted."
The Seniors have the negative
side of the question. Although it
has not been definitely decided,
the order of the 'speakers for the
two teams will in all probability
be as follows:
Juniors—Rothschild, Evans and
Duncan.
Seniors — Ed gett, Oppenheimer
and Steinbach.
As has been the custom in past
years, the Johns Hopkins Musical
Clubs will render selections on
the evening of the debate.
In addition to the debate, there
will be a public speaking contest
for the Adams medal between
three members of the Sophomore
Class—Mitchell B. Carroll, Maurice Glick and Corydon P. Gowman, Jr.
The arrangements for the intercollegiate debate are nearly complete, with the exception of the
selection of a date. It is thought,
however, that April 21 will be satisfactory to all concerned. Both
the University of Virginia and the
University of North Carolina have
agreed to the amended subject,
limiting the discussion to interstate railroads, which will be the
subject of the inter class debate.
The date for the Tocqueville
medal contest will be announced
next week. The Tocqueville medal
is annually given to the Johns
Hopkins University by the Baron
Pierre de Coubertin of Paris, and
University to

With an attendance of over
seventy-five couples, the second
cotillon of the year was held last
Friday in the Civil Engineering
Building.
Pretty girls blended with various class pennants dating back to
the days of University infancy,
while spritely young Hopkins students tripped the light fantastic
to their hearts' content. Louis
Fisher's orchestra blared forth
in sonorous tones syncopated
waltzes, fox-trots and one-steps.
At the end of the tenth dance
there was a triumphant march to
the "eats," which disappeared in
a manner clearly showing that
they were thoroughly enjoyed.
After this intermission all rushed
back to take up their terpsichorean duties.
At 1 o'clock the last strains of
"Home, Sweet Home" rolled out
across the campus, lights were
dimmed and the dancers wended
their way home.

AFTERWARD
Those awful days, those days of fearsome dread;
Those madd'ning nights, those nights of midnight oil,
Are gone, all gone. No longer need I toil
And force crammed knowledge through my aching head.
I think no more of penicillium thread,
No more of charter colony, or royal,
Of George's unearned produce of the soil,
Or anything that Mill or Bacon said.
My step is firm again, my head is high,
No longer.do I shrink from each new day.
The clouds'are gone; the sun shines in the sky;
And joyously I leap, and shout, and play..,
Away, ye books! Unlooked at shall ye lie
And gather dust until the end of May.
